Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech by creating two classes of citizens, allowing certain groups to spread misinformation while restricting others.
The internet is a democratic platform that should allow free expression, but the bill imposes excessive fines and restrictions.
Determining truth is complex and evolving; the bill could wrongly classify evolving information as misinformation.
Delegating legislative power to private entities is unconstitutional and lacks accountability.
The bill discourages public discourse and participation by ordinary citizens.
It poses threats to digital platform providers and users, encouraging a culture of reporting and eroding community spirit.
The bill contradicts Australia's commitments to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
Notable Quotes: The internet is undoubtedly the most powerful democratic invention of our time, providing a platform for regular people to voice their opinions and engage in meaningful discussions.
This bill not only undermines the freedom of speech of citizens but also discourages their participation in public discourse.
Delegating legislative power to private entities is an unconstitutional abdication of the legislative power of Parliament.
